{{otheruses}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group=Khanty |image=Ostjaken_vom_Ob_Ende_19tes_Jhdt.jpg |image_caption=Khanty from the Ob river |population = 31,000 <ref>http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/perepis_itogi1612.htm</ref> |popplace=[[Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug]] ([[Russia]]) |region1 = {{flag |Russia}} |pop1 = 30,943 (2010) |ref1 = <ref name= "пер.2010">{{cite web|url= http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/perepis_itogi1612.htm|script-title=ru:Официальный сайт Всероссийской переписи населения 2010 года. Информационные материалы об окончательных итогах Всероссийской переписи населения 2010 года|trans-title=Official site of the National Population Census 2010. Informational materials about the final outcome Russian Census 2010|language=ru|place=[[Russia|RU]]|publisher=GKS}}</ref> |region2 = {{flag |Ukraine}} |pop2 = 100 (2001) |ref2 = <ref>{{cite web|url= http://2001.ukrcensus.gov.ua/results/nationality_population/nationality_popul1/select_5/?botton=cens_db&box=5.1W&k_t=00&p=50&rz=1_1&rz_b=2_1%20%20%20&n_page=3|publisher=State statistics committee of Ukraine|title = National composition of population|year=2001 |work=Census|language=uk|place=[[Ukraine|UA]]}}</ref> |region3 = |pop3 = |ref3 = |rels=[[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodoxy]], [[Shamanism]] |langs=[[Russian language|Russian]], [[Khanty language|Khanty]] |related=[[Mansi people|Mansi]] }} [[File:Ostyak.jpg|thumb|right|Khanty man in [[Tomsk]], 2006.]] [[File:Khant_Family.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Khanty family standing in front of a [[chum (tent)|chum]], their traditional tent]] [[File:Map of Russia - Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug (2008-03).svg|thumb|200px|Most Khanty people live in the [[Khanty–Mansi Autonomous Okrug]] in western [[Siberia]]]] The '''Khanty''' (in older literature: '''Ostyaks''') are an [[indigenous people]] calling themselves ''Khanti, Khande, Kantek'' (Khanty), living in [[Khanty–Mansi Autonomous Okrug]], a region historically known as "[[Yugra]]" in [[Russia]], together with the [[Mansi people|Mansi]]. In the [[autonomous okrug]], the [[Khanty language|Khanty]] and [[Mansi language]]s are given co-official status with Russian. In the [[Russian Census (2010)|2010 Census]],<ref>http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/perepis_itogi1612.htm</ref> 30,943 persons identified themselves as Khanty. Of those, 26,694 were resident in [[Tyumen Oblast]], of which 17,128 were living in Khanty–Mansi Autonomous Okrug and 8,760—in [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug]]. 873 were residents of neighbouring [[Tomsk Oblast]], and 88 lived in the [[Komi Republic]].<!-- [http://www.raipon.org/russian_site/people/people_perepis_2002_rus.htm] -->
== History ==
In the centuries of the second millennium BC, the territories between [[Kama River|Kama]] and [[Irtysh River|Irtysh]] rivers were the home of a Proto-Uralic speaking population who had contacts with Proto-Indo-European speakers from the South.<ref name="Khanty">{{Cite book| last1 =Wiget| first1 =Andrew | last2= Balalaeva | first2= Olga | authorlink = | title = Khanty, People of the Taiga: Surviving the 20th Century | publisher = University of Alaska Press | year = 2011 | location = | pages =3 | url = | isbn = 978-16022-3125-2 | accessdate = }}</ref> The inhabitants of these areas were of Europid stock,<ref name="Khanty"/> although the Khanty are predominantly [[Uraloid]]. This woodland population is the ancestor of the modern-day Ugrian inhabitants of Trans-Uralia.<ref name="Khanty"/> Some consider the Khanty's ancestors to be the prehistoric [[metalworking]] [[Andronovo]] Culture. Other researchers say that the Khanty people originated in the south Ural steppe and moved northwards into their current location about 500 AD.<ref>{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/316322/Khanty-and-Mansi#ref272005 }}</ref>
Khanty probably appear in Russian records under the name [[Yugra]] (ca. 11th century), when they had contact with Russian hunters and merchants. The name comes from [[Komi-Zyrian language]] ''jögra'' ('Khanty'). It is also possible that they were first recorded by the English King [[Alfred the Great]] (ca. 9th century), who located Fenland ([[wetland]]) to the east of the White Sea in Western Siberia. The older Russian name Ostyak is from Khanty ''as-kho'' 'person from the Ob (''as'') River,' with -''yak'' after other ethnic terms like ''Permyak''.<ref>M. Vasmer, ''Etimologicheskii slovar russkogo yazyka'', Vol. III (Moscow, 1971), p. 167.</ref>
Some Khanty princedoms were partially included in the [[Siberia Khanate]] from the 1440s–1570s.
In the 11th century, [[Yugra]] was actually a term for numerous tribes, each having its own centre and its own chief. Every tribe had two [[exogamy|exogamic]] [[phratry|phratries]], termed ''mon't''' and ''por'', and all members were considered to be blood relatives. This structure was later replaced with [[clan]]s, where each clan leader (''knyazets'') negotiated with the Russian realm. They also participated in Russian campaigns, and received the right to collect ''yasaq'' (tribute) from two Khanty ''volosts'' (districts) respectively. When this structure was no longer needed, Russia deprived them of their privileges.
Between the 17th and 19th centuries, there were attempts to introduce [[Christianity]], but the Khanty lifestyle did not undergo any real changes. In the second half of 19th century, they gradually accepted state law.
During the [[USSR|Soviet]] period the Khanty were one of the few indigenous minorities of Siberia to be granted an autonomy in the form of an [[okrug]] (autonomous district). The establishment of autonomy has played a considerable role in consolidation of the ethnos (the Western Khants called their eastern neighbours ''Kantõk'' [the Other People]). However, in the 1930s concerted efforts were made by the Soviet state to collectivise them. The initial stages of this meant the execution of tribal chiefs who were labelled "[[kulak]]s" followed by the execution of [[shaman]]s. The abduction by the state of the children who were sent to Russian speaking boarding schools provoked a national revolt in 1933 called the [[Kazym rebellion]].
After the end of the [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] period this process was relaxed and efforts were intensified in the 1980s and '90s to protect their common territory from industrial expansion of various ministries and agencies. The autonomy has also played a major role in preserving the traditional culture and language.
== Economy == The Khantys' traditional occupations were fishery, taiga hunting and reindeer herding. They lived as trappers, thus gathering was of major importance.
== Organisation == The Khanty are one of the indigenous minorities in Siberia with an autonomy in the form of an [[okrug]] (autonomous area).
== Religion == Khanty are today Orthodox Christians, mixed with traditional beliefs (shamans, reincarnation). Their historical shaman wore no special clothes except a cap. Traditional Khanty cults are closely related to nature. The Crow spring celebration is being celebrated in April, nowadays it is April 7, the same day as the Annunciation day. The Bear Celebration is being celebrated occasionally after a successful hunting of a bear. The Bear Celebration continues 5 or 6 days (the duration depends on the sex of the animal). Over 300 songs and performances occur during a Bear Celebration. The most important parts of the celebration are: * Nukh Kiltatty Ar (The Awakening Song) * Ily Vukhalty Ar (The Coming Down From The Sky Song) - The story about the son of Torum (the sky god). The son was sent by Torum to rule the Earth. He has forgotten father's advice, lost his immortality, turned into a beast and has been killed by the hunters. * Il Veltatty Ar (The Lullaby)
== Language == {{main|Khanty language}} The Khanty language is a language belonging to the Ugric branch of the [[Uralic languages]], consisting of ten dialects, divided into southern, northern and eastern subgroups, and related to [[Mansi language|Mansi]] and [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]].
==Gallery== <gallery mode="packed-hover" heights="150px"> Khanty_children_in_front_of_a_reindeer_sledge.jpg|Khanty children pose for the camera in front of a reindeer sledge near Lake Numto Khanty_family.jpg|Khanty family at River Ob in the village of Tegi Khanty_old_women_in_Numsang_Yoh.jpg|Kazym grandmothers old women in Numsang Yoh nomad camp Khanty girls gathering berries.jpg|Khanty girls gathering berries Khanty people selling blueberries and stuffed animals (129).jpg|Khanty selling blueberries and stuffed animals </gallery>
== Notes == <references/>
== See also == * [[Iyrcae]]

page.title: Lionel Barrymore on stage, screen and radio
List of Book of Mormon people

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=May 2007}} {{Book of Mormon}} This list is intended as a quick reference for individuals mentioned in the [[Book of Mormon]].
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}
==Notation==
Names with superscripts (e.g., Nephi¹) are numbered according to the index in the [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS]] scripture, the Book of Mormon.<ref>[http://scriptures.lds.org/in/contents Index<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Missing indices indicate people in the index who are not in the Book of Mormon; for instance, Aaron¹ is the biblical [[Aaron]], brother of [[Moses]].
* '''Bold type''' indicates the person was an important religious figure, such as a [[prophet]] or a missionary. * ''Italic type'' indicates the person was a king, chief judge or other ruler. * <u>Underlined type</u> indicates the person was a historian or record keeper; one whose writing (abridged or not) is included in ''The Book of Mormon''. * Combined typefaces indicate combined roles. For example, '''''bold italic''''' indicates an individual was both a religious and secular leader.
<!-- Here's the superscript characters, if you want to copy and paste from here: ⁰¹²³⁴⁵⁶⁷⁸⁹ -->
==A== * ''[[Aaron (Jaredite)|Aaron]]²'', descendant of Heth² Jaredite king * [[Aaron (Nephite)|Aaron]]³, son of Mosiah², Nephite missionary * ''[[Aaron (Lamanite)|Aaron]]⁴'', Lamanite king (c. AD 330) * '''[[Abinadi]]''', Nephite prophet sent to people of Lehi-Nephi - converted Alma¹(c. 150 BC) * <u>[[Abinadom]]</u>, son of Chemish, Nephite historian, and Nephite warrior. * [[Abish (Book of Mormon)|Abish]], Lamanite woman, servant of Lamoni's wife * [[Aha (Book of Mormon)|Aha]], Nephite military officer (c. 80 BC) * ''[[Ahah (Book of Mormon)|Ahah]]'', son of Seth², Jaredite king * [[Akish]], son of Kimnor, Jaredite king * '''[[Alma the Elder|Alma¹]]''', Nephite prophet (c. 173-91 BC) * [[Alma the Younger|'''''Alma²''''']], son of Alma¹, known as ''Alma the Younger''. Nephite prophet and first chief judge (c. 100-73 BC). * <u>[[Amaleki]]¹</u>, Nephite record keeper (c. 130 BC) * [[Amaleki (Book of Mormon explorer)|Amaleki]]², seeker of Zeniff's people (c. 121 BC) * [[Amalickiah]], Nephite traitor who becomes king of the Lamanites and wars with Nephites - killed by Teancum (c. 70 BC) * [[Amaron]], son of Omni, Nephite record keeper * '''[[Aminadab]]''', Nephite dissenter living among the Lamanites - reconverted by Nephi² and Lehi⁴ (c. 30 BC) * ''[[Amgid]]'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|m|ɡ|ɪ|d}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ăm´gĭd»</ref> a Jaredite king. * [[Aminadi]], descendant of Nephi¹ * [[Amlici]], Nephite dissenter (c. 87 BC) * [[Ammah (Book of Mormon)|Ammah]], Nephite missionary, companion of Aaron³ * [[Ammaron]], Nephite record keeper (c. AD 306) * [[Ammon (Book of Mormon explorer)|Ammon¹]], leader of expedition to land of Nephi (c. 121 BC) * [[Ammon (Book of Mormon missionary)|Ammon²]], son of Mosiah², missionary to the Lamanites, becomes chief judge in land of Jershon to Anti-Nephi-Lehites (c. 100 BC) * [[Ammoron]], Nephite traitor, brother of Amalickiah, king of Lamanites after Amalickiah's death - killed by Teancum (c. 66-61 BC) * [[Amnigaddah]], son of Aaron², Jaredite king * [[Amnor]], Nephite spy in Amlicite campaign (c. 87 BC) * [[Amoron]], a Nephite officer and spy (c. AD 380-400) * [[Amos, son of Nephi|Amos]]¹, son of Nephi⁴, Nephite record keeper (c. AD 110-194) * [[Amos, son of Amos|Amos]]², son of Amos¹, Nephite record keeper (c. AD 194-306) * [[Amulek]], son of Giddonah¹, Nephite missionary, companion of Alma² * [[Amulon]], priest of King Noah, tributary Nephite monarch of Land of Helam * [[Antiomno]], Lamanite king of land of Middoni. * [[Antionah]], a chief ruler in Ammonihah * [[Antionum]], Nephite commander (c. AD 385) * [[Antipus]], Nephite commander in city of Judea.(c. 65 BC) * [[Archeantus]] ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|ɑːr|k|i|ˈ|æ|n|t|ə|s}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «är-kē-ăn´tus»</ref> Nephite soldier, one of three "choice men" (Moroni 9) slain in battle (c. AD 375)<ref name = "farms">http://preview.farmsresearch.com/publications/jbms/?vol=3&num=2&id=64</ref>
==B== * [[King Benjamin|'''''Benjamin''''']], known as ''King Benjamin'', Nephite prophet and king (c. 120 BC) * '''[[Brother of Jared]]'''², (also Mahonri Moriancumer),<ref>"The Jaredites," [[The Juvenile Instructor]], [1 May 1892], p. 282 n.</ref><ref>Chapter 48, Book of Mormon Student Manual, Religion 121 and 122, 1996</ref><ref>"Understanding the Scriptures", "Ether 2 The Jaredites Build Barges", Book of Mormon Seminary Student Study Guide, [2000]</ref> Jaredite prophet and the most prominent person in the account given in the beginning (Chapters 1 - 6) of the [[Book of Ether]].
==C== * [[Captain Moroni]], see Moroni¹ * ''[[Cezoram]]'', eighth Nephite chief judge (c. 30 BC), preceded by [[Nephi, son of Helaman]], and succeeded by his son, and eventually by [[#S|Seezoram]]. Cezoram and Seezoram are two different people and should not be confused with one another. * <u>[[Chemish]]</u>, son of Omni, Nephite record keeper * Christ, see [[Jesus Christ]] * [[Lineage of Ether|Cohor]]¹, brother of Noah² * ''[[Lineage of Ether|Cohor]]²'', early Jaredite king, son of Corihor¹ and brother to Noah. He joined his brother Noah, with "all his brethren and many of the people" to establish a rival kingdom to Shule’s ({{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Ether|chapter=7|verse=15}}). There are no further references, but he seems to have been influential, for his brother Noah later names a son after him ({{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Ether|chapter=7|verse=20}}) and the name is passed down to the end of the Jaredite lineage ({{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Ether|chapter=13|verse=17}}). * [[Cohor]]³, late Jaredite * ''[[Lineage of Ether|Com]]¹'' ({{IPAc-en|k|oʊ|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «kōm»</ref> early Jaredite king, son of Coriantum¹ * ''[[Lineage of Ether|Com]]²'', late Jaredite king * [[Corianton]] ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|k|ɒr|i|ˈ|æ|n|t|ən}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «kōr-ē-ăn´tun»</ref> son of Alma² * [[Lineage of Ether|Coriantor]], late Jaredite, son of [[Moron (Book of Mormon)|Moron]], father of [[Ether (prophet)|Ether]]. Although his father had been king, Coriantor "dwelt in captivity all his days".<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Ether|chapter=11|verse=19}}</ref> * ''[[Lineage of Ether|Coriantum]]¹'', early Jaredite king, son of Emer * [[Lineage of Ether|Coriantum]]², middle Jaredite, son of Amnigaddah * [[Coriantumr#Coriantumr .28son of Omer.29|Coriantumr]]³, early Jaredite, son of Omer * ''[[Coriantumr|Coriantumr¹]]'', Jaredite king, last Jaredite survivor * [[Coriantumr|Coriantumr²]], Nephite apostate, commander of Lamanite forces * [[Lineage of Ether|Corihor]]¹, son of Kib, early Jaredite * [[Lineage of Ether|Corihor]]², late Jaredite, not to be confused with [[Korihor]] * ''[[Corom]]'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɔːr|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «kōr´um»</ref> middle Jaredite king, son of Levi² * [[Cumenihah]] ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|k|uː|m|ə|ˈ|n|aɪ|h|ɑː}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «kū-ma-nī´hä»</ref> Nephite commander (c. AD 385)
<!-- No Ds -->
==E== * ''[[Emer (Book of Mormon)|Emer]]'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|iː|m|ər}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ē´mer»</ref> early Jaredite king and son of Omer. * [[Emron]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɛ|m|r|ɒ|n}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ĕm´rän»</ref> Nephite soldier <!--Disambig Link needed--> <!-- Enos¹, son of Adam, is not in BofM --> * '''[[Enos (Book of Mormon)|Enos²]]''', son of Jacob², Nephite prophet and record keeper * [[Esrom (Book of Mormon)|Esrom]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɛ|z|r|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ĕz´rum»</ref> early Jaredite and son of Omer. * ''[[Lineage of Ether|Ethem]]'', later Jaredite king and son of Ahah. * [[Ether (Book of Mormon prophet)]], Jaredite prophet and record keeper * '''Ezias''' ({{IPAc-en|iː|ˈ|z|aɪ|ə|s}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ē-zī´us»</ref> prophet referenced in [https://lds.org/scriptures/bofm/hel/8?lang=eng#20 Helaman 8:20]
<!-- No Fs -->

==H== * [[Hagoth]], Nephite shipbuilder (c. 55 BC) * [[Lineage of Ether|Hearthom]], middle Jaredite king and son of Lib¹. * [[Helam]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|iː|l|əm}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «hē´lum»</ref> convert from the people of Noah² (c. 147 BC). First of those baptized by Alma¹ * [[Helaman]]¹, son of [[King Benjamin]] (c. 130 BC), brother of [[King Mosiah II|Mosiah²]] and Helorum. Helaman is only mentioned in one verse.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Mosiah|chapter=1|verse=2}}</ref> * '''[[Helaman|Helaman²]]''', eldest son of Alma², prophet and military commander (c. 74-56 BC) * '''[[Helaman, son of Helaman|Helaman³]]''', eldest son of Helaman² - sixth Nephite chief judge * Helem ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|iː|l|ɛ|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «hē´lĕm»</ref> brother of Ammon² * [[Helorum, son of Benjamin|Helorum]] ({{IPAc-en|h|iː|ˈ|l|ɔːr|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «hē-lōr´um»</ref> son of [[King Benjamin]] (c. 130 BC), brother of [[King Mosiah II|Mosiah²]] and [[Helaman, son of King Benjamin|Helaman¹]]. Helorum is mentioned in only one verse,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> but is addressed with his brothers by King Benjamin.<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Mosiah|chapter=1|verse=2|range=-8}}</ref> * Hem ({{IPAc-en|h|ɛ|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «hĕm»</ref> brother of Ammon² * [[Heth (Book of Mormon)|Heth]]¹, early Jaredite and son of Com¹. * [[Heth (Middle Jaredite)|Heth]]², middle Jaredite and son of Hearthom. * [[Himni]], son of Mosiah² (c. 100-74 BC)

==M== * [[Mahah]], son of Jared³ * [[Manti (soldier)|Manti]], Nephite soldier (c. 87 BC) * [[Mathoni]] ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|θ|oʊ|n|aɪ}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «ma-thō´nī»</ref> one of twelve Nephite disciples (c. AD 34) * Mathonihah ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|m|æ|θ|oʊ|ˈ|n|aɪ|h|ɑː}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «măth-ō-nī´hä»</ref> one of twelve Nephite disciples (c. AD 34) * [[Lineage of Ether|Morianton]]¹ ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|m|ɒr|i|ˈ|æ|n|t|ən}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «mōr-ē-ăn´tun»</ref> Jaredite king and son of Riplakish. * Morianton², founder of the Nephite city of Morianton, Nephite traitor and ruler of the people of Morianton, instigator of the Lehi-Morianton border dispute. * Mormon¹, father of Mormon² * [[Mormon (prophet)|Mormon²]], abridger of the Nephite record, military commander, historian, record keeper. * [[Moron (Book of Mormon)|Moron]], late Jaredite king<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Ether|chapter=11|verse=14|range=-18}}</ref> who reigned during a time of great wickedness and turmoil, and was himself wicked. He lost half his kingdom for many years in a rebellion and, after regaining his kingdom, was completely overthrown and lived out his life in captivity. He was the grandfather of the prophet [[Ether (prophet)|Ether]]. * [[Captain Moroni|Moroni¹]], known as ''Captain Moroni'', Nephite military commander (c. 99-56 BC) * [[Moroni (Book of Mormon prophet)|Moroni²]], son of Mormon², Nephite prophet * [[Moronihah|Moronihah¹]], son of Moroni¹, Nephite general (c. 60 BC) * [[Moronihah]]², Nephite general who perished at the battle of [[Cumorah]], along with his ten-thousand (c. AD 385) * [[King Mosiah I|Mosiah¹]], Nephite prophet and king, father of King Benjamin * [[King Mosiah II|Mosiah²]], son of King Benjamin, Nephite prophet and king (c. 154-91 BC) * [[Mulek]], son of Jewish king Zedekiah * [[Muloki]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|j|uː|l|ə|k|aɪ}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «myū´la-kī»</ref> Nephite missionary
==N== * [[Nehor]], Nephite apostate, religious theorist (c. 91 BC) * [[Nephi, son of Lehi|'''''Nephi¹''''']], son of Lehi¹ * [[Nephi, son of Helaman|Nephi²]], son of Helaman² - seventh Nephite chief judge * [[Nephi the Disciple|Nephi³]], son of Nephi², known as Nephi the Disciple * [[Nephi, son of Nephi the Disciple|Nephi]]⁴, son of Nephi³ * ''[[Nephihah]]'' ({{IPAc-en|n|iː|ˈ|f|aɪ|h|ɑː}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «nē-fī´hä»</ref> second Nephite chief judge (c. 83-67 BC). He succeeded [[Alma the Younger]] when Alma had surrendered the judgment seat to him to devote more time to missionary work.<ref>Alma4:17-18</ref> His son [[Pahoran]] inherited the judgment seat from him after his death.<ref>Alma 50:37-39</ref> * '''[[Neum (prophet)|Neum]]''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|iː|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «nē´um»</ref> Hebrew prophet quoted by Nephi¹ * '''Nimrah''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|ɪ|m|r|ɑː}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «nĭm´rä»</ref> son of Akish, Jaredite * ''[[Noah]]²'', son of Corihor¹, early Jaredite king * ''[[Noah]]³'', son of Zeniff, Nephite king
==O== * ''[[Omer (Book of Mormon)|Omer]]'', early Jaredite king and son of Shule. * '''[[Omner]]''', [[Sons of Mosiah|son of Mosiah²]] * [[Omni (Book of Mormon)|<u>Omni</u>]], son of Jarom, Nephite record keeper * ''[[Orihah]]'', first Jaredite king
==P== * [[Paanchi (Book of Mormon)|Paanchi]], son of Pahoran¹, Nephite rebel (c. 52 BC) * ''[[Pachus]]'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|eɪ|k|ə|s}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «pā´kus»</ref> king of Nephite dissenters in land of Zarahemla (c. 61 BC) * [[Pacumeni]] ({{IPAc-en|p|eɪ|ˈ|k|j|uː|m|ə|n|aɪ}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «pā-kyū´mĕn-ī»</ref> son of Pahoran¹ fifth Nephite chief judge (c. 52 BC), brother of [[Pahoran#Pahoran, son of Pahoran|Pahoran, the son of Pahoran]], and a contender for the judgement-seat over the people of Nephi.<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Helaman|chapter=1|verse=3}}</ref> After the death of his brother Pahoran, Pacumeni acquired the judgement-seat,<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Helaman|chapter=1|verse=13}}</ref> but he didn't keep it long; for the land was being invaded by Lamanites, and [[Coriantumr]], a large and mighty man and descendant of [[Zarahemla (person)|Zarahemla]] and dissenter from the Nephites, caught Pacumeni in his attempt to run away, and killed him at the city walls. [[Helaman, son of Helaman]], succeeded him as chief judge. * [[Pagag]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|eɪ|ɡ|ɑː|ɡ}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «pā´gäg»</ref> son of Brother_of_Jared² * ''[[Pahoran|Pahoran¹]]'', son of Nephihah, third Nephite chief judge (c. 68 BC) * ''[[Pahoran#Pahoran, son of Pahoran|Pahoran²]]'', son of Pahoran¹, fourth Nephite chief judge, killed by Kishkumen (c. 52 BC)
<!-- No Qs -->
==R== * [[Lineage of Ether|Riplakish]] ({{IPAc-en|r|ɪ|p|ˈ|l|eɪ|k|ɪ|ʃ}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «rĭp-lā´kĭsh»</ref> Jaredite king and son of Shez¹.
==S== * [[Sam (Book of Mormon)|Sam]], third son of Lehi¹ (c. 600 BC) * '''[[Samuel the Lamanite|Samuel²]]''', Lamanite prophet (c. 6 BC) * [[Sariah]], wife of Lehi¹ (c. 600 BC) * [[Seantum]] ({{IPAc-en|s|i|ˈ|æ|n|t|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «sē-ăn´tum»</ref> member of Gadianton band (c. 23 BC) * ''[[Seezoram]]'' ({{IPAc-en|s|iː|ˈ|z|ɔːr|əm}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «sē-zōr´um»</ref> member of Gadianton band, tenth known Nephite chief judge (c. 26 BC), eventually succeeded by [[Lachoneus]]. How and when he began his reign as chief judge is not known; his first appearance in the [[Book of Mormon]] is when [[Nephi, son of Helaman]], prophesied his murder by the hand of his brother, [[Seantum]]. To give the wicked Nephites a sign that he, Nephi, was a prophet, he prophesied this murder to his people.<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Helaman|chapter=8|verse=27|range=-28}}</ref><ref>See also {{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Helaman|chapter=9|verse=20|range=-37}}</ref> Seezoram should not be confused with [[#C|Cezoram]], another Nephite chief judge who was assassinated earlier. * [[Lineage of Ether|Seth]]², son of Shiblom¹, Jaredite * [[Shared (Book of Mormon)|Shared]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|eɪ|r|ə|d}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shā´rud»</ref> Jaredite military leader * [[Shem]]², Nephite commander (c. AD 385) * '''[[Shemnon]]''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|ɛ|m|n|ɒ|n}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shĕm´nän»</ref> one of twelve Nephite disciples (c. AD 34) * [[Sherem]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|ɛr|əm}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shĕr´um»</ref> an antichrist (c. fifth century BC). [[Hugh Nibley]] states that "Sherem" means "snub nosed or pug nosed."<ref>[[Hugh Nibley|Nibley, Hugh]] & Hummel, Sharman Bookwalter (ed.) ''Nibley's Commentary on the Book of Mormon, Vol. 1'' (2013), ASIN: B00GFY0GUO</ref> * [[Lineage of Ether|Shez]]¹ ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|ɛ|z}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shĕz»</ref> early Jaredite king and son of Heth¹. * [[Shez]]², son of Shez¹ * ''[[Shiblom]]¹'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|ɪ|b|l|ə|m}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shĭb´lum»</ref>) (also Shiblon),<ref>Shiblom is mentioned in Ether 1:11-12, where he is identified as Shiblon, but it is clear from the context that it is the same individual whose troubled reign is described in Ether 11:4-9.</ref> late Jaredite king and son of Com². * [[Shiblom|Shiblom²]], Nephite commander (c. AD 385)<ref>{{sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Mormon|chapter=6|verse=14}}</ref> * [[Shiblon]], son of Alma², Nephite missionary & record-keeper * [[Shiz]], Jaredite military leader * [[Jaredite kings|Shule]] ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|uː|l}}),<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shūl»</ref> early Jaredite king

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{More citations needed|date=February 2018}}{{Infobox basketball biography | name = Manute Bol | image = Manute Bol 2006.jpg | caption = Bol in 2006 | height_ft = 7 | height_in = 7 | weight_lbs = 200 | birth_date = {{birth date|1962|10|16|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Turalei]] or [[Gogrial]], [[History of Sudan (1956–69)|Sudan]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|06|19|1962|10|16|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], U.S. | college = [[University of Bridgeport#Athletics|Bridgeport]] (1984–1985) | nationality = Sudanese / American | draft_year = 1985 | draft_round = 2 | draft_pick = 31 | draft_team = [[Washington Bullets]] | career_start = 1985 | career_end = 1996 | career_position = [[Center (basketball)|Center]] | career_number = 10, 11, 4, 1 | years1 = 1985 | team1 = [[Rhode Island Gulls]] | years2 = {{nbay|1985|start}}–{{nbay|1987|end}} | team2 = [[Washington Bullets]] | years3 = {{nbay|1988|start}}–{{nbay|1989|end}} | team3 = [[Golden State Warriors]] | years4 = {{nbay|1990|start}}–{{nbay|1992|end}} | team4 = [[Philadelphia 76ers]] | years5 = {{nbay|1993|full=y}} | team5 = [[Miami Heat]] | years6 = {{nbay|1993|end}} | team6 = Washington Bullets | years7 = {{nbay|1993|end}} | team7 = Philadelphia 76ers | years8 = {{nbay|1994|full=y}} | team8 = Golden State Warriors | years9 = 1995–1996 | team9 = [[Florida Beach Dogs]] | years10 = 1996 | team10 = C. Montana Forlì | highlights = * [[NBA All-Defensive Second Team]] ({{nbay|1985|end}}) * 2× [[List of National Basketball Association season blocks leaders|NBA blocks leader]] ({{nbay|1985|end}}, {{nbay|1988|end}}) | stats_league = NBA | stat1label = [[Point (basketball)|Points]] | stat1value = 1,599 (2.6 ppg) | stat2label = [[Rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]] | stat2value = 2,647 (4.2 rpg) | stat3label = [[Block (basketball)|Blocks]] | stat3value = 2,086 (3.3 bpg) | bbr = bolma01 }} '''Manute Bol''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|n|uː|t|_|ˈ|b|oʊ|l}}; October 16, 1962 – June 19, 2010) was a Sudanese-born American [[basketball]] player and political [[activist]]. Listed at {{height|ft=7|in=7}} tall, he was the tallest player in the history of the [[National Basketball Association]], along with [[Gheorghe Mureșan]].<ref>{{cite book|last= Brown|first= Donald H.|title=A Basketball Handbook|year= 2007|publisher=AuthorHouse| isbn= 978-1-4259-6190-9| page=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YJmsqtj-rh4C&pg=PA20| location=Bloomington, Indiana}}</ref> He was officially measured and listed at {{convert|7|ft|6+3/4|in}} tall in the ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]''. He is believed to have been born on October 16, 1962, in either [[Turalei]] or [[Gogrial]], [[History of Sudan (1956–69)|Sudan]]. He was the son of a [[Dinka people|Dinka]] tribal elder who gave him the name Manute, which means "special blessing".
Bol played for two colleges and four NBA teams over his career. A [[center (basketball)|center]], he was known as a specialist player and was considered among the best shot-blockers in the history of the sport despite other aspects of his game being considered fairly weak. Over the course of his career, Bol blocked more shots than he scored points, making him the only NBA player ever to do so. He is second all-time in NBA history in terms of average [[block (basketball)|blocked shots]] per game and ranks 15th on the [[List of National Basketball Association career blocks leaders|career blocks list]].
==Early life and family background== Manute Bol was born to Madute and Okwok Bol in Turalei or Gogrial and raised near Gogrial. His date of birth was not recorded; college basketball coach [[Kevin Mackey]] listed Bol's birthday as October 16, 1962, but believed he was actually much older.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Stefan|title=Manute Bol lied about his age, may have been 50 years old when he played in the NBA: report|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/basketball/manute-bol-lied-age-50-played-nba-article-1.3649488|website=NY Daily News|accessdate=November 22, 2017|date=November 21, 2017}}</ref> Bol came from a family of extraordinarily tall men and women: "My mother was {{height|ft=6|in=10}}, my father {{height|ft=6|in=8}}, and my sister is {{height|ft=6|in=8}}", he said. "And my great-grandfather was even taller—{{height|ft=7|in=10}}." His ethnic group, the Dinka, and the [[Nilotic peoples|Nilotic people]]<ref>{{cite journal |last = Roberts |first = D. F. |author2=D. R. Bainbridge |title = Nilotic physique |journal = Am. J. Phys. Anthropol. |volume = 21 |issue = 3 |pages = 341–70 |date = Sep 1963 |doi = 10.1002/ajpa.1330210309 }}</ref> of which they are a part, are among the taller populations of the world. Bol's hometown, Turalei, is the origin of other exceptionally tall individuals, including {{height|ft=7|in=4}} basketball player Ring Ayuel. Ayuel is a refugee from the [[Second Sudanese Civil War|civil war]] which broke out soon after Bol emigrated to the U.S. and which eventually led to the destruction of most of Turalei.<ref>{{cite web|last=Steward |first=Carl |title=His spirit, giant: Sudanese player embraced at Ohlone College |publisher=Inside Bay Area (via Ohlone College) |date=12 Jan 2011 |url=http://www.ohlone.edu/org/athletics/mensbasketball/teamnews20102011/20110112sudaneseplayer.html |accessdate=2013-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018030948/http://www.ohlone.edu/org/athletics/mensbasketball/teamnews20102011/20110112sudaneseplayer.html |archivedate=2013-10-18 |df= }}</ref>
He tended his family's cattle in boyhood. According to a tale he was often asked to repeat in interviews, he once killed a lion with a spear after it attacked his cattle. The lion was asleep, though he was often encouraged to embellish the story. He started playing basketball only at about age 15.
Complementing his great [[human height|height]], Bol possessed exceptionally long limbs (inseam {{convert|49|in|cm}}) and large hands and feet ([[Shoe size|size]] 16 {{small|1/2}}). His [[arm span]], at {{convert|8|ft|6|in|m}}, is (as of 2013) the longest in NBA history, and his reach was {{convert|10|ft|5|in|m}}.<ref name="WaPo obit"/><ref>{{cite web |title = Former NBA player Manute Bol to speak at Union |publisher = Union College |date = Nov 3, 2008 |url = http://www.union.edu/N/DS/s.php?s=8105 |accessdate = 2012-12-08 }}</ref> He was extremely slender, limiting his offensive capability. When he arrived in the United States, he weighed {{convert|180|lb|kg}}<ref>{{cite news |last = Epting |first = Chris |title = The Manute We Knew: Curious, Shy, One of the Family . . . and a Lion Slayer |newspaper = AOL News |date = Jun 24, 2010 |url = http://www.aolnews.com/2010/06/24/the-manute-we-knew-curious-shy-one-of-the-family/ |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130117040047/http://www.aolnews.com/2010/06/24/the-manute-we-knew-curious-shy-one-of-the-family/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = January 17, 2013 }}</ref> and had gained just under {{convert|20|lb|kg}} by the time he entered the NBA. The Washington Bullets sent Bol to strength training with [[University of Maryland]] coach Frank Costello, where he could initially lift only {{convert|44|lb|kg}} on 10-repetition [[bench press]] and {{convert|55|lb|kg}} on 10-repetition [[squat (exercise)|squat]]<ref>{{cite journal |last = McCallum |first = Jack |title = Welcome To 'Air Bol': Stronger and heavier, the Bullets' 7'7" Manute Bol could be a force |journal = Sports Illustrated |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = Oct 21, 1985 |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1120035/ }}</ref> (his [[body mass index]] was 15.3 and he initially had a 31" (80 cm) waist).<ref>{{cite news |last = McManis |first = Sam |title = At 7 Foot 6, Manute Bol of Sudan Is Surely Rangy Enough for America's City Game and He Has Talent, but at 190 Pounds He May Not Be Strong Enough for Big Time: Basketball's Tallest Story |newspaper = Los Angeles Times |pages = |date = Feb 11, 1985 |url = http://articles.latimes.com/1985-02-11/sports/sp-4394_1_manute-bol }}</ref>
==Basketball career==
===Amateur years=== Bol started playing [[Association football|soccer]] (association football) in 1972, but abandoned the game because he was too tall.<ref>{{cite news |title = Sudan's NBA giant |newspaper = BBC News |date = 29 Oct 2001 |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/1626514.stm }}</ref> During his later teens, he started playing basketball, playing in Sudan for several years with teams in [[Wau, Sudan|Wau]] and [[Khartoum]], where he experienced prejudice from the northern Sudanese majority.<ref>{{cite book |last = |first = |title = Contemporary Black Biography |chapter = Manute Bol |publisher = Thomson Gale |edition = |location = Detroit |pages = |url = |isbn = }}</ref> While still living in Sudan, Bol apparently held an $80-a-month (1983 US$) job in the Sudanese military and played on the national team.<ref name="USAToday">{{cite news|title=Scouts: Bol has slim chance at success|date=April 12, 1985|first=Kathy|last=Blumenstock|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|page=}}</ref> Coach [[Don Feeley]] from [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]] saw Bol play basketball in Khartoum and convinced him to go to the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/manute-bol|title=Answers - The Most Trusted Place for Answering Life's Questions|website=Answers.com|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref> Bol was drafted by the [[San Diego Clippers]] in the fifth round of the [[1983 NBA draft]] (97th overall), but the league ruled that Bol had not been eligible for the draft and declared the pick invalid.<ref>{{cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |title = Manute Bol |work = |publisher = The Draft Review |url = http://www.thedraftreview.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2159 |accessdate = 2012-12-10 }}</ref> He was then invited to [[Cleveland]] by [[Cleveland State University]] head basketball coach [[Kevin Mackey]], but he did not speak or write English very well at the time. He improved his English skills after months of classes at [[ELS Language Centers]] on the [[Case Western Reserve University]] campus, but not enough to qualify for enrollment at Cleveland State, and he never played a game there. Five years later, Cleveland State was placed on two years' probation for providing improper financial assistance to Bol and two other African players.<ref>{{cite news |last = Associated Press |title = Penalties Upheld for Cleveland State |newspaper = The New York Times |pages = |date = Apr 22, 1988 |url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE6D9173AF931A15757C0A96E948260 }}</ref> He enrolled at the [[University of Bridgeport]], a Division II basketball school, and played college basketball for the Purple Knights there in the 1984–1985 season. He averaged 22.5 points, 13.5 rebounds, and 7.1 blocks per game. The team, which previously drew 500–600 spectators, routinely sold out the 1,800-seat gym.<ref name="USAToday"/> This was followed by a short stint with the [[Rhode Island Gulls]] of the [[United States Basketball League]].
===NBA=== {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2016}}
Going into the [[1985 NBA draft]], scouts felt that Bol needed another year or two of college, but Bol opted for the draft because he felt that it was the only way to earn enough money to get his sister out of Sudan, which was in a state of political unrest at the time.<ref name="USAToday"/> In 1985, Bol was drafted as the seventh pick in the second round by the [[Washington Bullets]] (31st overall). He played in the NBA for ten seasons, from 1985 to 1995, spending parts of four seasons with the Bullets, parts of three with the [[Golden State Warriors]], parts of four with the [[Philadelphia 76ers]], and part of one season with the [[Miami Heat]]. In 1987, the Bullets drafted the {{height|ft=5|in=3}} [[point guard]] [[Muggsy Bogues]], pairing the tallest and shortest players in the league on the court for one season.
====Washington Bullets==== {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2016}}
Bol's first tenure with the Bullets lasted three seasons, from 1985 to 1988. In his rookie season ([[1985–86 NBA season|1985–1986]]), he appeared in 80 games and recorded a career-high 5.0 blocks per game. His total of 397 blocks set the NBA [[rookie]] record, and remains the second-highest single-season total in league history behind [[Mark Eaton (basketball)|Mark Eaton]]'s 456 in 1984–85.
====Golden State Warriors==== Bol's first tenure with the Golden State Warriors lasted for two seasons, from 1988 to 1990. In his first season with Golden State, he first attempted three-point shots with regularity. In that season, he shot a career-high 91 three-pointers and made 20 of them. During this time, he may have helped to popularize the expression "[[wikt:my bad|my bad]]", although a 2005 suggestion that he coined the phrase has been discounted.<ref name="Pullum">{{cite web|url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/002693.html|title=Language Log: Pick-up basketballism reaches Ivy League faculty vocabulary|last=Pullum|first=Geoffrey K. |authorlink=Geoff Pullum |date=7 December 2005|accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visualthesaurus.com/cm/wordroutes/2327/|title=The Manute Bol Theory of "My Bad"|last=Zimmer|first=Ben |authorlink=Ben Zimmer |date=22 June 2010|work=Word Routes|publisher=Thinkmap Visual Thesaurus|accessdate=2010-06-23}}</ref>
====Philadelphia 76ers==== Bol's first tenure with the Philadelphia 76ers lasted for three seasons, from 1990 to 1993. Although he played in a career-high 82 games in his first season as a 76er, his production began to decline afterward (in both games played and per-game statistics). After playing in all 82 games in [[1990–91 NBA season|1990–1991]], he played in 71 games the [[1991–92 NBA season|next season]], and in 58 (a career low at the time) games the [[1992–93 NBA season|following season]]. During his last season in Philadelphia, he had a memorable night playing against former teammate [[Charles Barkley]] and the Phoenix Suns, hitting 6 of 12 three-pointers, all in the second half in a losing effort.<ref>{{cite web |title = Philadelphia 76ers at Phoenix Suns Box Score, March 3, 1993 |work = Basketball Reference.com |publisher = Sports Reference |url = https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/PHO19930303.html |accessdate = 2012-12-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071216132101/http://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/PHO19930303.html |archivedate = December 16, 2007 |df = }}</ref> Fans were known to yell out "shoot" as soon as Bol received the ball far from the basket.<ref>Kerry Eggers, "Around the League", The Sunday Oregonian, March 7, 1993</ref>
====Miami Heat==== Bol played in eight games in the [[1993–94 NBA season|1993–1994 season]] with the [[Miami Heat]], the only team that did not use him as a starter. He scored only one two-point field goal with the team and blocked six shots in 61 total minutes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/b/bolma01.html|title=Manute Bol Stats {{!}} Basketball-Reference.com|website=Basketball-Reference.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-09}}</ref>
====Washington Bullets (2nd stint)==== Bol's second stint with the Bullets lasted only two games in 1993–1994. After this, he helped develop fellow 7 ft 7 teammate [[Gheorghe Mureșan]].<ref name=":0" />
====Philadelphia 76ers (2nd stint)==== Bol's second stint with the 76ers lasted for four games, near the end of the 1993–1994 season, helping to mentor {{height|ft=7|in=6}} teammate [[Shawn Bradley]]. In only 49 minutes, he played more aggressively than he did earlier in the season with Miami and Washington. He scored six points, grabbed six rebounds and blocked nine shots.<ref name=":0" />
====Golden State Warriors (2nd stint)==== In the [[1994–95 NBA season]], Bol returned to the Warriors. He made the season-opening roster and played in what would be his final five NBA games. On a memorable night in the middle of November, Bol finally made his home debut, coming off of the bench to play 29 minutes against the Minnesota Timberwolves. Bol attempted three three-pointers in the fourth quarter, scoring all of them.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/b/bolma01/gamelog/1995/|title=Manute Bol 1994-95 Game Log {{!}} Basketball-Reference.com|website=Basketball-Reference.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-09}}</ref> Seven nights later in Charlotte, in a game that was nationally televised by [[Turner Network Television|TNT]], he was in the starting lineup again. By this time, two weeks into the season, his career seemed rejuvenated under Warrior head coach [[Don Nelson]]; he was again a defensive force, making threes and contributing as a starter to create matchup problems. After playing only ten minutes against the Hornets on November 22, 1994, he suffered a season-ending knee injury. Before he left the game, he recorded one block and two points and attempted a three-pointer in ten minutes of play.<ref name=":1" />
Bol was waived by Golden State on February 15, 1995.<ref name=":0" />
====Shot blocking==== With his great height and very long limbs, Bol was one of the league's most imposing defensive presences. Along with setting the rookie shot-blocking record in 1985–86, over the course of his career, Bol tied for the NBA record for the most blocked shots in one half (11) and in one quarter (eight, twice).<ref>{{cite web |title = Regular Season Records: Blocked Shots |work = NBA Encyclopedia |publisher = National Basketball Association |url = http://www.nba.com/history/records/regular_blockedshots.html |accessdate = 2012-12-10 }}</ref> On {{Dts|1992|January|31}}, in a game against the [[Orlando Magic]], he blocked four consecutive shots within a single possession.<ref name="FSN">{{cite episode |title = Manute Bol: Beyond the Glory |episodelink = |url = |series = |serieslink = |credits = |network = FOX Sports Net |station = |city = |airdate = Apr 17, 2005 |began = |ended = |season = |seriesno = |number = |minutes = |transcript = |transcripturl= }}</ref> Throughout his career, he blocked a shot an average of every 5.6 minutes of playing time.<ref name="SI 01">{{cite journal |last = Anderson |first = Kelli |title = Manute Bol: Once the NBA's premier shot blocker, the Sudanese Sultan of Swat has tried to bring peace to his homeland |journal = Sports Illustrated |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = Jul 2, 2001 |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1022915/ }}</ref>
However, Bol's other basketball skills were very limited, and his rail-thin physique made it difficult for him to establish position against the league's bulkier centers and power forwards. The sight of the tall, gangly Bol spotting up for a three-pointer during blow-outs became a fan favorite. Off the court, he established a reputation as a practical joker; Charles Barkley, a frequent victim of his pranks, attested to Bol's sense of humor.<ref>{{cite web | last = Narducci | first = Marc | title = Tough Time for a Tall Guy His sense of humor could be a help to Manute Bol as he seeks to recover his health after a serious car crash. | publisher = Philly.com | date = Jul 8, 2005 | url = http://articles.philly.com/2004-07-18/sports/25371302_1_manute-bol-neville-h-robinson-sixers }}</ref> Bol also developed a close friendship with Warriors teammate [[Chris Mullin (basketball)|Chris Mullin]] and named one of his sons after him.
====Career accomplishments==== Over the course of his career, Bol averaged 2.6 points, 4.2 rebounds, 0.3 assists, and 3.3 blocks per game, while only playing an average of 18.7 minutes per game. Bol finished his career with totals of 1,599 points, 2,647 rebounds, and 2,086 blocks, having appeared in 624 games over 10 seasons.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = basketball-reference.com |title = Manute Bol |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/b/bolma01.html |accessdate = 2008-05-29 }}</ref> As of 2010, Manute Bol remains: * First in career blocks per 48 minutes (8.6), almost 50% beyond second-place [[Mark Eaton (basketball)|Mark Eaton]] (5.8).<ref>{{cite web |title = Career Leaders for Blocks Per 48 Minute |work = Basketball Reference.com |publisher = Sports Reference |url = https://www.basketball-reference.com/play-index/psl_finder.cgi?request=1&sum=1&type=per_minute&per_minute_base=48&is_playoffs=N&year_min=1947&year_max=2010&season_start=1&season_end=-1&age_min=0&age_max=99&height_min=0&height_max=99&lg_id=&franch_id=&is_active=&is_hof=&pos=&qual=&c1stat=mp&c1comp=gt&c1val=1000&c2stat=&c2comp=gt&c2val=&c3stat=&c3comp=gt&c3val=&c4stat=&c4comp=gt&c4val=&order_by=blk_per_mp |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref> * Second in career blocks-per-game average (3.34).<ref>{{cite web |title = Career Leaders and Records for Blocks Per Game |work = Basketball Reference.com |publisher = Sports Reference |url = https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/BPG_career.html |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref> * Fifteenth in total blocked shots (2,086).<ref name="blk_career">{{cite web |title = Career Leaders and Records for Blocks |work = Basketball Reference.com |publisher = Sports Reference |url = https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/BLK_career.html |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref> * The only player in NBA history to block more shots than points scored, blocking 2,086 shots and scoring 1,599 points.<ref name="blk_career"/>
===After the NBA=== After the end of his NBA career, Bol played 22 games for the Florida Beach Dogs of the [[Continental Basketball Association]] during the 1995–1996 season. The Beach Dogs' games against the [[Sioux Falls Skyforce]] in that season were broadcast by [[ESPN]], as the Skyforce also featured a former NBA player, [[Darryl Dawkins]]. In 1996, the Portland (Maine) Mountain Cats of the [[United States Basketball League]] announced that he would be playing with the team, and included him in the team program, but he never appeared in uniform. He then played professionally in Italy in 1997 and had a stint in [[Qatar]] in 1998 before [[rheumatism]] forced him to retire permanently.<ref name="SI 01"/>

==Activism== Bol was very active in charitable causes throughout his career. In fact, he said he spent much of the money he made during a 10-year NBA career supporting various causes related to the war-ravaged nation of his birth, Sudan.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zumoff |first=Marc |title=Catching up with Manute Bol |journal=Drive |volume= |issue= |pages= |publisher=NBA Media Ventures |url=http://www.nba.com/sixers/features/drive_manute_bol_070807.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215162830/http://www.nba.com/sixers/features/drive_manute_bol_070807.html |archivedate=2007-12-15 |df= }}</ref> He frequently visited Sudanese refugee camps, where he was treated like royalty. In 2001, Bol was offered a post as minister of sport by the Sudanese government. Bol, who was a Christian,<ref>{{cite news |last = Shields |first = Jon A. |title = Manute Bol's radical Christianity |newspaper = The Wall Street Journal |pages = |date = Jun 25, 2010 |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704853404575323043046894012 }}</ref> refused because one of the conditions was converting to [[Islam]].<ref name="focusdep.com">{{cite web|last=Luo |first=Michael |title=NBA Star Now Refugee |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.focusdep.com/articles/Society/NBA_Star_Now_Refugee |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223041640/http://www.focusdep.com/articles/Society/NBA_Star_Now_Refugee |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-02-23 |accessdate= }}</ref> Later, Bol was hindered from leaving the country by the Sudanese government, who accused him of supporting the Dinka-led Christian rebels, the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]]. The Sudanese government refused to grant him an exit visa unless he came back with more money. Assistance by supporters in the United States, including [[Connecticut]] Senator [[Joseph Lieberman]], raised money to provide Bol with plane tickets to Cairo, Egypt. After 6 months of negotiations with U.S. consulate officials regarding refugee status, Bol and his family were finally able to leave Egypt and return to the United States.<ref name="focusdep.com"/>
Bol established the [[Ring True Foundation]] to continue fund-raising for [[Sudanese refugees]]. He gave most of his earnings (an estimated $3.5 million) to their cause. In 2002, [[Fox TV]] agreed to broadcast the telephone number of his Ring True Foundation in exchange for Bol's agreement to appear on their ''[[Celebrity Boxing]]'' show. After the referee goaded, "If you guys don't box, you won't get paid", he scored a third-round victory over former [[American football|football]] player [[William Perry (American football)|William "The Refrigerator" Perry]].
In the fall of 2002, Bol signed a one-day contract with the [[Indianapolis Ice]] of the [[Central Hockey League]]. Though he could not skate, the publicity generated by his single-game appearance helped raise money to assist children in Sudan.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=184|isbn = 1-894974-21-2 }}</ref> Bol once suited up as a horse jockey for similar reasons.
Bol was involved in the April 2006 [[Sudan Freedom Walk]], a three-week march from the [[United Nations]] building in New York City to the [[United States Capitol]] in Washington, DC. The event was organized by [[Simon Deng]], a former Sudanese swimming champion (currently a lifeguard at [[Coney Island]]), who was a longtime friend of Bol's. Deng, who was a [[Slavery|slave]] for three years from the age of nine, is from another tribe in Southern Sudan. His Sudan Freedom Walk is especially aimed at finding a solution to the [[genocide]] in [[Darfur]] (western Sudan), but it also seeks to raise awareness of the modern-day slavery and human-rights abuses throughout Sudan. Bol spoke in New York City at the start of the walk, and in [[Philadelphia]] at a rally organized by former hunger striker [[Nathan Kleinman]].
Bol was also an advocate for reconciliation efforts, and worked to improve education in South Sudan. A Nicholas Kristoff article<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/24/opinion/24kristof.html?_r=3&ref=nicholasdkristof |newspaper=The New York Times |first=Nicholas D. |last=Kristof |title=Most Valuable Helper |date=Jun 23, 2010}}</ref> in ''The New York Times'' highlighted this belief and Bol's work for reconciliation and education with an organization called [[Sudan Sunrise]]. Bol first began working with Sudan Sunrise to raise awareness on issues of reconciliation in 2005. This included speaking at the United States Capitol in Washington, DC, and subsequently partnering with Sudan Sunrise to build schools across South Sudan that, in the spirit of reconciliation, would enroll students regardless of tribe or religion.<ref>{{cite web |title = Manute Bol School |work = Current Projects in South Sudan |publisher = Sudan Sunrise |url = http://www.sudansunrise.org/project/manute-bol-school |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref>
During his time in Egypt, Bol ran a basketball school in [[Cairo]]. One of his pupils was a fellow Sudanese refugee, [[Los Angeles Lakers]] player [[Luol Deng]], the son of a former Sudanese cabinet minister. Deng later moved to the United States to further his basketball career, continuing a close relationship with Bol.
==Life after basketball== Despite initially knowing little English and an absence of awareness regarding Western culture, Bol adjusted and was widely regarded as a well-rounded personality who was inquisitive and well-read. He developed a strong friendship with Charles Barkley, who remarked, "If everyone in the world was a Manute Bol, it's a world I'd want to live in. He's smart. He reads ''The New York Times''. He knows what's going on in a lot of subjects. He's not one of these just-basketball guys".<ref name="SI 90">{{cite journal |last = Montville |first = Leigh |title = A Tall Story: Manute Bol, the Sixers' 7'7" center, views life from a unique perspective |journal = Sports Illustrated |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = Dec 17, 1990 |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1136052/ }}</ref> He spoke [[Dinka language|Dinka]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]] before mastering English.<ref>{{cite journal |last = Lidz |first = Franz |title = Come See The Dinka Dunker Do: Manute Bol, an import from Sudan, is giving a 7'6" lift to Bridgeport |journal = Sports Illustrated |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = Dec 10, 1984 |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1122922/ }}</ref>
After a political dispute in Sudan, Bol was admitted to the United States as a religious refugee in 2002 and settled in [[West Hartford, Connecticut]].<ref name="WaPo obit"/> In July 2004, he was seriously injured in a car accident in [[Colchester, Connecticut|Colchester]] when he was ejected from a taxi that hit a guardrail and overturned, resulting in a broken neck.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Tracy Gordon|last2=Farrell|first2=Jim|title=Bol critically injured in car accident|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1914&dat=20040702&id=GxAqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nmQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1174,283134|accessdate=8 July 2014|work=The Hartford Courant|date=2 July 2014}}</ref> The driver was under the influence, with a suspended license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://compuserve.nba.com/sixers/features/manute_bol_060822.html|title=Where Are They Now: Manute Bol|publisher=|accessdate=27 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709140413/http://compuserve.nba.com/sixers/features/manute_bol_060822.html|archivedate=9 July 2012|df=}}</ref> Because his fortunes were mostly donated to Sudan, he was financially ruined because he had no health insurance.<ref name="FSN"/> When he recovered from his injuries, he moved to [[Olathe, Kansas]].<ref name="WaPo obit"/>
Bol was also the "Brand Ambassador" for [[Ethiopian Airlines]] and Ethiopian Airlines Journeys.
One of Bol's sons, Madut (born December 19, 1989), played college basketball at [[Southern Jaguars basketball|Southern University]] and graduated from college in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/2010-06-29-manute-bol-funeral_N.htm|title=Manute Bol remembered as 'also a giant off the court' at funeral|date=June 29, 2010|work=USA Today|accessdate=March 23, 2014}}</ref> Another son, [[Bol Bol]], is a {{height|ft=7|in=3}}-tall 12th grader as of January 2018 and played basketball for [[Findlay Prep]] in [[Henderson, Nevada]], after first transferring from [[Bishop Miege High School]] in [[Roeland Park, Kansas]], to [[Mater Dei High School (Santa Ana, California)|Mater Dei]] in [[Santa Ana, California]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://usatodayhss.com/2014/manute-bols-son-bol-bol-is-dominating-jv-hoops-in-kansas |title=Manute Bol's son, Bol Bol, is dominating JV hoops in Kansas |last=Smith |first=Cam |date=12 December 2014 |website=usatodayhss.com |publisher=USA Today High School Sports |access-date=24 February 2015}}</ref> Bol Bol is considered a top recruit for the class of 2018 and committed to join the [[Oregon Ducks men's basketball|Oregon Ducks]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theplayerstribune.com/bol-bol-oregon-ducks-basketball/|title=Shoes to Fill {{!}} By Bol Bol|website=The Players' Tribune|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> Bol's nephew [[Peter Jok]] previously played basketball at the [[University of Iowa]] and currently plays for the [[Northern Arizona Suns]] of the [[NBA G League]].
==Death== On June 19, 2010, Bol died from [[acute kidney failure]] and complications from [[Stevens–Johnson syndrome]] at the [[University of Virginia Health System|University of Virginia Medical Center]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]].<ref name="WaPo obit">{{cite news|last=Schudel|first=Matt |title=Manute Bol, former Washington Bullet and one of NBA's tallest players, dies at 47|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/19/AR2010061902214.html|accessdate=19 June 2010|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=19 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.pitch.com/plog/2010/06/manute_bol_retired_basketball_player_has_died.php |title=Manute Bol, retired basketball player, has died |last=Kendall |first=Justin |date=June 19, 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-19 |publisher=The Pitch |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100622032557/http://blogs.pitch.com/plog/2010/06/manute_bol_retired_basketball_player_has_died.php |archivedate=June 22, 2010 |df= }}</ref> He was survived by his 10 children, six <!--(Madut, Chris, Abuk, and Akak)--> with his first wife, Along, and four with his second wife, Ajok.<ref>{{cite news |last = McGeehan |first = Patrick |title = Manute Bol, N.B.A. Player and Activist, Dies at 47 |newspaper = The New York Times |pages = |date = Jun 19, 2010 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/20/sports/basketball/20bol.html?scp=2 }}</ref>
After his death, tributes to Bol's basketball career and charitable works came from around the United States and the world.<ref>{{cite news |last = Jasner |first = Phil |title = Remembering the best of times with former NBA player Manute Bol |newspaper = The Philadelphia Inquirer |date = Jun 21, 2010 |url = http://articles.philly.com/2010-06-21/sports/24965043_1_don-feeley-dinka-tribesman-manute-bol |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/local-opinions/2010/06/manute_bols_other_legacy.html | work=The Washington Post |title=Manute Bol's other legacy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/gallery/2010/06/19/GA2010061902220.html |work=The Washington Post|title=Manute Bol, former Washington Bullet: 1962-2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/sports/basketball/articles/2010/06/22/manute_bol_had_height_of_course_but_even_more_depth |work=The Boston Globe |title=Height, and depth |first=Bob |last=Ryan |date=June 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>http://www.courant.com/news/opinion/editorials/hc-editorial-manute-bol-20100622,0,5943117.story{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>http://www.kctv5.com/news/23978190/detail.html{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>{{Excessive citations inline|date=February 2018}} His former teams, and the NBA, issued statements in recognition of his impact on the sport of basketball and on his native Sudan.<ref>{{cite web |last = Leonsis |first = Ted |title = Ted Leonsis' Statement on Passing of Manute Bol |work = Washington Wizards news |publisher = NBA Media Ventures |date = Jun 19, 2010 |url = http://www.nba.com/wizards/news/bol_100619.html |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Former Warrior Manute Bol Passes Away |work = Golden State Warriors news |publisher = NBA Media Ventures |date = Jun 19, 2010 |url = http://www.nba.com/warriors/news/bol_passes_away_061810.html |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last = Stefanski |first = Ed |title = Philadelphia 76ers statement on the passing of Manute Bol |work = Philadelphia 76ers news |publisher = NBA Media Ventures |date = Jun 19, 2010 |url = http://www.nba.com/sixers/news/bol_100619.html |accessdate = 2012-12-14 }}</ref> Kansas senator [[Sam Brownback]] paid tribute to Bol on the floor of the United States Senate just a few days after his death.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/video/2010/06/22/VI2010062202905.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |title=Video: A Senate salute to Manute |date=2010-06-22}}</ref>
==Funeral service and tribute== [[File:Manute Bol's funeral at National Cathedral 2010-06-29 1.jpg|thumb|Bol's memorial service at the National Cathedral]]
The memorial service for Manute Bol was held on Tuesday, June 29, 2010, at 10:00 am at the National Cathedral in Washington, DC. Bol's body lay in an eight-foot-long, specially built casket.<ref name="google.com">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5j4CZIgXsXmROD8dYFKNNhS3BpA2w] {{dead link|date=September 2016}}</ref>
Bol was given tributes by United States Senator [[Sam Brownback]] from Kansas, former National Security Advisor [[Robert McFarlane]], Sudan's Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Akec Khoc Acieu, Bol's uncle Bol Bol Chol, and vice president of the [[National Basketball Players Association]] [[Rory Sparrow]].<ref name="google.com" />
Sparrow remembered Bol as "a giant off the court", who should be remembered for humanitarian work and his basketball career.<ref name="google.com" /> Senator Brownback recalled, "He literally gave his life for his people. He went over [to Sudan], he was sick. He stayed longer than he should have. He probably contracted this ailment that took his life while in Sudan, and he didn't have to do that. He was an NBA basketball player. He could have stayed here and had an easy life. I've never seen anybody use his celebrity status more nor give his life more completely to a group of people than Manute Bol did. It makes me look at efforts that I do as not enough."
Dr. Akec K.A. Khoc, Ambassador of Sudan to the U.S., said, "Manute had a very great heart for his country and people. He did everything to support anybody in need of shoes, blankets, health service, food, and people who were struggling. He went to see them and to encourage them to continue their struggle for their rights, for their freedoms. Manute embodied everything we can think of in Sudan. Reconciling warring groups between the north and south, in Darfur he was working for reconciliation between Darfur and the south and between Darfur and the rest of Sudan. So, Manute was a voice for hope."
[[Sudan Sunrise]] founder, Tom Prichard, says Bol's work to reconcile former enemies lives on. "Manute's legacy and vision of education and reconciliation, his determination to grow [[grassroots]] reconciliation—whether that reconciliation is expressed in a country that divides or holds together, wherever the boundary lines are drawn. Manute stood for grassroots reconciliation."<ref name="www1.voanews.com">{{cite news |title=Dignitaries, Friends Say Farewell to NBA's Manute Bol |publisher=VOA News |date=Jun 28, 2010 |url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Dignitaries-Friends-say-Farewell-to-NBA-Manute-Bol-97432534.html |accessdate=2012-12-14}}</ref> Prichard went on to say "There's no question Manute gave his life for his country."<ref name="kansascity.com">http://www.kansascity.com/2010/06/22/2036636/nba-legend-spent-his-life-helping.html</ref><ref name="kansascity.com" />
Manute Bol's family [[patriarch]], Bol Bol Chol, said, "This man is not an ordinary man. I believe this man is a messenger like other messengers who were sent into this world—to do something in this world. He has accomplished most of his mission, and so God took him and left the rest of the work to be done by others."<ref name="www1.voanews.com" />
Bol is buried in [[South Sudan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kmbc.com/news/24214449/detail.html|title=Memorial To Honor Manute Bol|publisher=|accessdate=27 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307131045/http://www.kmbc.com/news/24214449/detail.html|archivedate=7 March 2012|df=}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[List of National Basketball Association players with most blocks in a game]] * [[List of tallest players in National Basketball Association history]] * [[List of tallest people]]

'''Marcus Aemilius Lepidus''' was a name used by several [[ancient Romans|ancient Roman men]] of the ''[[Aemilia (gens)|gens Aemilia]]''. In the mid-3rd century BC, the [[Aemilii Lepidi]] split into two branches: the ancestors of the [[Second Triumvirate|triumvir]] usually named the eldest son Marcus, and the younger Lucius or Quintus, while the other Lepidi more often preferred the ''[[praenomen]]'' Manius.<ref>Richard D. Weigel, ''Lepidus: The Tarnished Triumvir'' (Routledge, 1992, 2002), p. 6. {{ISBN|978-0415076807}}</ref>
* [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (consul 232 BC)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, consul in 232 BC]] and 221 BC and augur * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (consul 187 BC)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, consul in 187 BC]] and 175 BC, [[Pontifex Maximus]] 180–152 BC, and [[Roman censor|censor]] * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (consul 158 BC)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, consul in 158 BC]] * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (consul 78 BC)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, consul in 78 BC]] and leader of a revolt defeated the next year * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (triumvir)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, member of the Second Triumvirate]], consul in 46 BC and 42 BC, Pontifex Maximus 44–12 BC, son of the consul in 78 BC * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus Minor]], only son of the triumvir by his wife Junia Secunda, sister of Marcus Junius Brutus * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (consul 6)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, consul in AD 6]] and general during the Illyrian War * [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (executed 39)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, executed in AD 39]], nephew of the previous consul and brother-in-law of Caligula
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lepidus, Marcus Aemilius}} [[Category:Articles about multiple people in ancient Rome]] [[Category:Aemilii Lepidi]] [[Category:Ancient Roman prosopographical lists]]
